instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00164: What is 820-00164? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: LOUIS-- <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Partially Blown Fuse!????
threads.message: I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> from another shop with no water damage, green light, but no power. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is at 1-2V so I imagine a short. Visual inspection and <CAPACITOR>C7314</CAPACITOR> is destroyed. I replace it and still no power/fan and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is now 4.5V. After measuring around forever, I finally measure BOTH pins of F7140, pin 2 is at 4.5 and pin 1 is 8.6. I measure for continuity and there is none! Has anyone ran into a partially blown fuse before?? I still consider myself a novice-- Louis, I think I have seen all of your videos, but I have never heard of this??

threads.title: LOUIS-- <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Partially Blown Fuse!????
threads.message: You measure no continuity so the fuse is not partially dead it is dead dead. How some voltage leaks around it can be through any component.

threads.title: LOUIS-- <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Partially Blown Fuse!????
threads.message: See if there is a short to ground on the other side of the fuse. If there isn't, replace the fuse.
